revisions.rev:
{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2002 |Team=Iowa Hawkeyes |Image= |ImageSize= |Conference=Big Ten Conference |Division= |ShortConference=Big Ten |CoachRank=8 |APRank=8 |Record=11-2 |ConfRecord=8-0 |HeadCoach=[[Kirk Ferentz]] |OffCoach=[[Ken O'Keefe]] |DefCoach=Norm Parker |OScheme= |DScheme= |StadiumArena=[[Kinnick Stadium]] -
70,397 |Champion=Big Ten Co-Champions |BowlTourney=[[2003 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] |BowlTourneyResult=L 38-17 vs. [[2002 USC Trojans football team|USC]] }} {{2002 Big Ten football standings}} The '''2002 Iowa Hawkeyes football team''' represented the [[University of Iowa]] during the [[2002 NCAA Division I-A football season|2002 college football season]]. The Hawkeyes played their home games at [[Kinnick Stadium]] in [[Iowa City, Iowa|Iowa City]], [[Iowa]] and were coached by [[Kirk Ferentz]]. Finishing the regular-season with an 11-1 record, they were an undefeated 8-0 in the [[Big Ten]] with the one loss coming to rival [[2002 Iowa State Cyclones football team|Iowa State]]. However, even with all the regular season success that included a Co-[[Big Ten Conference football champions|Big Ten championship]], the Hawkeyes could do little right in the [[2003 Orange Bowl]], and lost 38-17 to the [[2002 USC Trojans football team|USC]] Trojans. Despite the humbling loss, the 11 wins is an Iowa record for wins in a single season. ==Preseason== Coming off a 7-5 season that included an [[Alamo Bowl]] victory over [[Texas Tech University|Texas Tech]], things were looking up for the [[Iowa Hawkeyes]]. However, the Hawkeyes had to replace six offensive starters and four defensive starters. Quarterback [[Brad Banks]] and running back [[Fred Russell (football player)|Fred Russell]] looked to take a much bigger role in the offense. Russell would ultimately secure the starting spot as junior [[Aaron Greving]] decided to quit the team. Tight end [[Dallas Clark]] would also play a big role in the passing game. On defense, the Hawkeyes lost all-conference defensive tackle [[Aaron Kampman]], but had three players - [[Fred Barr]], [[Benny Sapp]], and [[Bob Sanders]] - on the [[Bronko Nagurski Trophy|Nagurski]] watch list. However on August 5, 2002 Benny Sapp was arrested for disorderly conduct, resisting arrest and public intoxication leading to his being kicked off the team before the season started and his eventual transfer to the University of Northern Iowa and leaving the Hawkeyes very thin at cornerback. In total, Iowa returned six defensive starters as opposed to only five offensive starters. The Hawkeyes also returned punter David Bradley and kicker [[Nate Kaeding]]. For lack of experience on offense, the Hawkeyes were unranked in both polls to start the season. They were also picked by [[Sports Illustrated]] to have a season similar to the year before, saying that another trip to the Alamo Bowl "should be viewed as a success." {{cite news | title=Iowa Hawkeyes 2002 College Football Preview| accessdate=2007-06-16 | url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/football/college/2002/preview/iowa/ | publisher=SI.com }} ==Schedule== {{CFB Schedule Name ! Position ! Years at Iowa |- | [[Kirk Ferentz]] | Head Coach | Three Years |- | [[Ken O'Keefe]] | Offensive Coordinator and Quarterbacks | Three Years |- | Norm Parker | Defensive Coordinator and Linebackers | Three Years |- | Chris Doyle | Strength and Conditioning | Three Years |- | Lester Erb | Receivers and Special Teams | Two Years |- | Carl Jackson | Running Backs | Three Years |- | Reese Morgan | Recruiting and Tight Ends | Two Years |- | Ron Aiken | Defensive Line | Three Years |- | Phil Parker | Defensive Backs | Three Years |- | Darrell Wilson | Linebackers and Special Teams | Two Years |} ==Game notes== ===University of Akron=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Zips |R1=0 |R2=14 |R3=7 |R4=0 |Home='''Hawkeyes''' |H1=37 |H2=14 |H3=3 |H4=3 }} Iowa's offense proved unstoppable as [[Fred Russell (football player)|Fred Russell]] and [[Jermelle Lewis]] combined for 293 of the Hawkeyes' 376 rushing yards. Quarterback [[Brad Banks]] was steady in his debut, completing five of his eight passes, two for touchdowns. Wide receiver [[Maurice Brown|Mo Brown]] was on the receiving end of both of Banks' touchdowns. The defense was suspect at times (nearly 300 passing yards by Akron), but linebacker [[Kevin Worthy]] picked up the slack with a 72-yard [[fumble]] return for a touchdown. Iowa's 37 points in the first quarter was a school record for points in a single quarter.{{cite news | title=Akron vs. Iowa| accessdate=2007-06-17 | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores102/102243/20020831NCAAFIOWA------0nr.htm#RCPS | publisher=USA TODAY }} {{-}} ===Miami University=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Hawkeyes''' |R1=7 |R2=6 |R3=9 |R4=7 |Home=Redhawks |H1=0 |H2=10 |H3=7 |H4=7 }} Facing a [[Ben Roethlisberger]]-led Miami squad, the Hawkeyes struggled to a five-point victory. [[Fred Russell (football player)|Fred Russell]] ran for over 100 yards for the second straight week and [[Maurice Brown|Mo Brown]] caught five passes for 115 yards and one touchdown. [[Brad Banks|Banks]] went head-to-head with Roethlisberger, throwing for 256 yards. Roethlisberger passed the ball 51 times, and completed 33 of them for 343 yards but had two interceptions. Capitalizing on several Iowa mistakes, the RedHawks were in the game late into the fourth quarter but could not pull off the upset at home. {{-}} ===Iowa State University=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Cyclones''' |R1=7 |R2=0 |R3=23 |R4=6 |Home=Hawkeyes |H1=7 |H2=17 |H3=0 |H4=7 }} Having not beaten their in-state rivals in the four previous seasons, the Hawkeyes quickly grabbed a 17-point [[halftime]] lead. But [[Iowa State Cyclones football|Iowa State's]] [[Seneca Wallace]] was not about to leave [[Iowa City, Iowa|Iowa City]] with a loss. Coupled with two [[Brad Banks|Banks]] fumbles in Iowa territory, a stellar performance by the senior quarterback led to 29 straight Iowa State points. Despite holding Iowa State to 85 yards rushing, Iowa's last touchdown was a little too late, and the Cyclones ran out the clock after Iowa failed an [[onside kick]] attempt. {{-}} ===Utah State University=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Aggies |R1=0 |R2=7 |R3=0 |R4=0 |Home='''Hawkeyes''' |H1=14 |H2=10 |H3=24 |H4=0 }} For the second straight week, the [[Iowa Hawkeyes|Hawkeyes]] held a 24-7 advantage at halftime. But this time, the Hawks did all the scoring in the 3rd quarter to salt the game away. Iowa was without starting running back [[Fred Russell (football player)|Fred Russell]] but [[Jermelle Lewis]] did an excellent job in replacement. The sophomore had 109 yards on only 9 rushes. The Hawkeyes also got scores off a blocked punt by [[Sean Considine]] recovered by [[Mike Follett]] and a fumble recovery by [[Jared Clauss]]. As a team, the Hawkeyes racked up exactly 300 yards rushing and 518 yards of total offense. {{-}} ===Penn State University=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Hawkeyes''' |R1=17 |R2=9 |R3=9 |R4=0 |R5=7 |Home=Nittany Lions |H1=0 |H2=7 |H3=6 |H4=22 |H5=0 }} Iowa opened up [[Big Ten]] play against the #12 team in the country, the [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State Nittany Lions]]. On the heels of three quick touchdowns and one field goal, the Hawkeyes opened up the game with an unexpected 23-0 lead. When Penn State finally got on the scoreboard, Iowa quickly answered back with a [[Nate Kaeding]] 55-yard field goal as time expired in the first half. Holding a 35-13 lead going into the 4th quarter, things were looking ripe for a Hawkeye upset. But Penn State quarterback [[Zach Mills (football player)|Zach Mills]] had the game of his career and threw three touchdown passes in the final 7:13 to tie the game at 35. Mills had a total of 399 passing yards in the game. However, Penn State was not able to answer an Iowa touchdown in the first overtime and for the first time since 1996, Iowa had beaten a ranked opponent on the road.{{cite news | title=Iowa vs. Penn State| accessdate=2007-06-18 | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores102/102271/20020928NCAAFPENNST----0nr.htm | publisher=USA TODAY }} {{see also|2002 Penn State Nittany Lions football team}}{{-}} ===Purdue University=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Boilermakers |R1=7 |R2=7 |R3=0 |R4=14 |Home='''Hawkeyes''' |H1=3 |H2=7 |H3=14 |H4=7 }} In a game that was full of big plays, Iowa did just enough to win on Homecoming weekend. Iowa scored three times on special teams, once on a blocked field goal, once on a blocked punt and once on a 51-yard [[Nate Kaeding]] field goal. But even a 95-yard touchdown pass from [[Brad Banks]] to [[Dallas Clark]] wasn't enough to keep the [[Purdue Boilermakers|Boilermakers]] from making a comeback. Scoring on two rushing touchdowns in the 4th quarter, Purdue quickly turned a 10-point deficit into a four-point lead. And after Banks was sacked on 4th down with only 2:44 remaining, it seemed as if Purdue would escape with the victory. But the Boilermakers could do nothing with their three downs and had to punt the ball away. Banks wasted no time, running for a 44-yard gain to the Purdue 43 on the first play of the drive. Later, on 4th down from the Purdue seven-yard line, Banks connected with Clark once again, this time for the game-winning touchdown. Purdue had one last chance, but a late interception by [[Adolphus Shelton]] secured the Iowa victory. {{-}} ===Michigan State University=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Spartans |R1=7 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=9 |Home='''Hawkeyes''' |H1=17 |H2=10 |H3=17 |H4=0 }} [[University of Iowa|Iowa's]] defense was strong against [[Michigan State University|Michigan State]], as the Hawkeyes held the Spartans to just 249 yards of total offense. No one really stood out on offense, but the Hawkeyes once again got scores from the defense and the special teams. Immediately following a Spartan touchdown, Iowa's [[Jermelle Lewis]] returned the kick 94 yards for the touchdown. Later in the 1st quarter, [[Derek Pagel]] took an interception 62 yards for the touchdown. [[C.J. Jones]] scored twice on passes from [[Brad Banks]] as Iowa scored 44 consecutive points spanning the first three quarters. Iowa also held Michigan State's [[Charles Rogers (American football)|Charles Rogers]] from scoring a touchdown, ending Rogers' consecutive game streak with a touchdown reception at 14.{{cite news | title=Michigan State vs. Iowa| accessdate=2007-06-19 | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores102/102285/20021012NCAAFIOWA------0.htm | publisher=USA TODAY }} {{-}} ===Indiana University=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Hawkeyes''' |R1=17 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=7 |Home=Hoosiers |H1=0 |H2=0 |H3=3 |H4=5 }} Running back [[Fred Russell (football player)|Fred Russell]] was the star on offense, running for 110 yards and two touchdowns. But aside from [[Grant Steen]]'s three interceptions and the eight points allowed, the defense was not up to par. The [[Iowa Hawkeyes|Hawkeyes]] allowed 480 yards of total offense, including 334 yards passing by [[Indiana University Bloomington|Indiana's]] [[Gibran Hamdan]]. The Hawkeyes also made several mental errors by fumbling the ball twice while [[Brad Banks]] threw a rare interception. The game could have been much closer had Steen not intercepted all three passes deep in Iowa territory. The three interceptions is also an Iowa single-game record.{{cite news | title=Iowa vs. Indiana| accessdate=2007-06-20 | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores102/102292/20021019NCAAFINDIANA---0.htm | publisher=USA TODAY }} {{-}} ===University of Michigan=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Hawkeyes''' |R1=10 |R2=0 |R3=14 |R4=10 |Home=Wolverines |H1=0 |H2=6 |H3=3 |H4=0 }} Behind a solid effort from running back [[Jermelle Lewis]] and wide receiver [[C.J. Jones]], the Hawkeyes quickly jumped out to a 10-0 lead. And if it were not for a fumble punt, the game wouldn't have gotten any closer. As it is, [[University of Michigan|Michigan's]] [[Chris Perry (football player)|Chris Perry]] scored moments later and [[University of Iowa|Iowa]] took a 10-6 lead into halftime. After a Michigan field goal pushed the score to 10-9, Iowa took over. The Hawkeyes scored 24 unanswered points to finish the game as Lewis and Jones racked up two touchdowns each. Quarterback [[Brad Banks]] threw for 222 yards and three touchdowns as Iowa handed Michigan their worst home loss since 1967.{{cite news | title=Straight to the Banks| accessdate=2007-06-18 | url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/football/college/news/2002/10/26/iowa_michigan_ap/ | publisher=SI.com }} {{-}} ===University of Wisconsin=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Badgers |R1=0 |R2=3 |R3=0 |R4=0 |Home='''Hawkeyes''' |H1=0 |H2=10 |H3=10 |H4=0 }} Quarterback [[Brad Banks]] threw for a career-high 275 yards while the [[Iowa Hawkeyes|Hawkeye]] defense held the [[Wisconsin Badgers|Badgers]] to just 78 yards rushing. In total, Wisconsin had 215 yards of offense. Iowa's [[Maurice Brown|Mo Brown]] and [[Dallas Clark]] finished with a combined 204 receiving yards and had both of Iowa's touchdowns. As a result of Iowa's powerful defense, Wisconsin lost two quarterbacks to injury, [[Brooks Bollinger]] and [[Jim Sorgi]]. Iowa's defense also held running back [[Anthony Davis (Canadian football)|Anthony Davis]] to a career-low 34 yards on 16 rushes. After the victory, Iowa was 6-0 in the [[Big Ten]] for the first time in school history.{{cite web | title=Hawkeyes 'Badger' Wisconsin| accessdate=2007-06-20 | url=http://iowa.rivals.com/content.asp?CID=139532 | publisher=HawkeyeReport.com }} {{-}} ===Northwestern University=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Wildcats |R1=7 |R2=3 |R3=0 |R4=0 |Home='''Hawkeyes''' |H1=14 |H2=21 |H3=21 |H4=6 }} On Senior Day, [[Brad Banks]] was a perfect 10-for-10 for 197 yards and three touchdowns. He also scored on two of Iowa's four rushing touchdowns. Iowa's receivers were busy as [[Maurice Brown|Mo Brown]], [[Dallas Clark]] and [[C.J. Jones]] all had touchdowns. Freshman wideout [[Ed Hinkel]] even got in on the action, scoring on a 58-yard punt return. Running back [[Fred Russell (football player)|Fred Russell]] returned from a hand injury, and ran for 100 yards in becoming Iowa's 10th player to have a 1,000-yard rushing season. Iowa's victory tied a school record for wins in a season at 10.{{cite news | title=Northwestern vs. Iowa| accessdate=2007-06-21 | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores102/102313/20021109NCAAFIOWA------0nr.htm | publisher=USA TODAY | date=2002-07-23}} {{-}} ===University of Minnesota=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Hawkeyes''' |R1=14 |R2=14 |R3=7 |R4=10 |Home=Golden Gophers |H1=7 |H2=7 |H3=7 |H4=0 }} [[University of Iowa|Iowa's]] defense forced six Minnesota turnovers en route to a 45-21 victory. The Hawkeyes only had 100 yards passing, mainly because their running game couldn't be stopped. [[Fred Russell (football player)|Fred Russell]] and [[Jermelle Lewis]] combined for 295 of Iowa's 365 rushing yards while [[Brad Banks]] threw for two touchdowns and ran for two touchdowns. [[Maurice Brown|Mo Brown]] caught his tenth touchdown pass of the season, which tied [[Quinn Early]] for touchdown receptions in a season. The win was Iowa's tenth straight [[Big Ten]] win, the longest such streak since a 13-game streak in the 1920s. The game was also played in front of the largest crowd to ever see a [[Minnesota Golden Gophers football]] game at the [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome|Metrodome]].{{cite news | title=Iowa vs. Minnesota| accessdate=2007-06-21 | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores102/102320/20021116NCAAFMINNESOTA-0.htm | publisher=USA TODAY | date=2002-07-23}} {{see also|2002 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team}}{{-}} ===Orange Bowl - University of Southern California=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Hawkeyes |R1=10 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=7 |Home='''Trojans''' |H1=7 |H2=3 |H3=14 |H4=14 }} The game opened up with a bang for the Hawkeyes, as [[C.J. Jones]] took the opening kickoff 100-yards for the touchdown. But as it turns out, it would be the only time until late in the fourth quarter that the Hawkeyes would see the [[endzone]]. Although the game was tied at [[halftime]], [[University of Southern California|USC]] blocked Iowa's last-second field goal, preventing a possible Iowa lead at the half. From there, [[Heisman Trophy|Heisman]] winner [[Carson Palmer]] went to work. The senior quarterback threw for over 300 yards against the [[Big Ten]]'s worst passing defense and led scoring drives of 79, 80, 99, 85 and 61 yards as the Trojans held a 16-minute advantage in time of possession. The USC defense was suffocating and Iowa's miscues were proof. The Hawkeyes had two turnovers, 13 penalties, and multiple missed opportunities. {{-}} ==Postseason Awards== *[[Kirk Ferentz]] - Named the [[Walter Camp Coach of the Year]]. *[[Brad Banks]] - [[Associated Press College Football Player of the Year Award|AP Player of the Year]], [[Davey O'Brien Award]]http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/awards?awardId=3 winner and second in [[Heisman Trophy]] voting. Also received first-team All-American honors along with [[University of Southern California|USC's]] [[Carson Palmer]] and [[University of Miami|Miami's]] [[Ken Dorsey]]. *[[Nate Kaeding]] - Winner of the [[Lou Groza Award]],http://www.lougrozaaward.com/ presented to the nation's best kicker. Also received first-team All-American honors along with [[Ohio State University|Ohio State]] kicker [[Mike Nugent]]. *[[Dallas Clark]] - Winner of the [[John Mackey Award]],http://www.johnmackeyaward.org/ given to the nation's best tight end. Consensus first-team All-American. *[[Eric Steinbach]] - Consensus first-team All-American. *[[Bruce Nelson (American football)|Bruce Nelson]] - First-team All-American honors. ==Team Players drafted into the NFL== {|class="wikitable" width="80%" |- align="center" style="background:black;color:yellow;" | '''Player''' || '''Position''' || '''Round''' || '''Pick''' || '''NFL Club''' |- align="center" bgcolor="" | [[Dallas Clark]]||Tight End|| 1 || 24|| [[2003 Indianapolis Colts season|Indianapolis Colts]] |- align="center" bgcolor="" | [[Eric Steinbach]]||Guard||2 || 33 || [[2003 Cincinnati Bengals season|Cincinnati Bengals]] |- align="center" bgcolor="" | [[Bruce Nelson (American football)|Bruce Nelson]]||Center|| 2 || 50 || [[2003 Carolina Panthers season|Carolina Panthers]] |- align="center" bgcolor="" | [[Derek Pagel]]||Defensive Back||5 || 140 || [[2003 New York Jets season|New York Jets]] |- align="center" bgcolor="" | [[Ben Sobieski]]||Guard||5 || 151 || [[2003 Buffalo Bills season|Buffalo Bills]] |- align="center" bgcolor="" |}http://www.pro-football-reference.com/draft/2003.htm ==References== {{Reflist}} {{IowaFootballSeasons}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2002 Iowa Hawkeyes Football Team}} [[Category:2002 NCAA Division I-A football season|Iowa]] [[Category:2002 Big Ten Conference football season|Iowa]] [[Category:Iowa Hawkeyes football seasons]] [[Category:Big Ten Conference football champion seasons]]
